abstracts.cdata!:
The Emergency Project to Assist Jordan
            Partially Mitigate Impact of Syrian Conflict Project for
            Jordan received a satisfactory outcome rating with low risk
            to development outcome. The Bank received a highly
            satisfactory outcome rating while the Borrowers performance
            rating was satisfactory. There were no restructurings of
            this project and the project components remained unchanged
            for the life of the project. The only change that occurred
            was a fund reallocation from Component 1 subcomponent for
            financing of health care services for drugs and vaccines.
            There were several lessons gained from this project and
            include the following: (1) Simplicity of operation through
            existing delivery mechanisms for existing services which
            allowed for quick preparation and implementation. (2)
            Flexibility of financial response through the inherent
            flexibility of the newly introduced OP 10.00 helped expedite
            preparation and the World Banks overall ability to respond
            with speed to an urgent need. (3) The financial managment
            approach was streamlined and based on more simplified ex
            ante requirements, while relying more heavily on ex post
            requirements as additional fiduciary controls and review
            which allowed for timely disbursements. (4) Flexibility in
            the design mechanism which provided for disbursements
            against payments for expenditures allowed for the project
            design to remain relevant and be responsive to any changes
            during implementation in policies towards health and basic
            social needs coverage and expenditures. (5) Retroactive
            financing for a substantial amount of 40 percent was key to
            the success of the emergency operation. (6) Temporary
            time-bound support in emergency situations to help meet
            essential household needs. These pro-poor interventions
            through subsidies and price controls can help mitigate the
            potential for social instability. (7) A strong relationship
            between the Bank and the government on the ground allowed
            for a rapid response. (8) The smooth coordination between
            the different units within the World Bank was outstanding
            and significantly contributed to the timely project
            preparation and as well the smooth implementation.
